commits.author: Allan Odgaard
commits.summary: Improve support for gems in “Open Require” (<kbd class='keyEquivalent'>⇧⌘D</kbd>)
commits.body: The previously reworked command would only handle the root gem file, e.g. ‘sinatra’ but not ‘sinatra/base’. It would also fail for gems that have a slash/dash in their name, for example ‘rack/protection’ is one gem named ‘rack-protection’ (and not a file named ‘protection’ in the ‘rack’ gem).

commits.author: Allan Odgaard
commits.summary: Rework “Open Require” (<kbd class='keyEquivalent'>⇧⌘D</kbd>) to work inside gems and for require_relative
commits.body:
The command previously used ruby 1.8 and therefore would only search for includes and gems using ruby 1.8’s load path.

Furthermore, it would not support `require_relative` nor would it handle a `require` inside of a gem (since that `require` would be relative to the gem’s load path).

The previous command would, when used on a line without a `require` or `load` statement, search the entire file and present a menu. I have not replicated this behavior, as it’s not something I have ever used myself. I think a better behavior would be to open an input dialog, like the C bundle’s Quick Open.

Lastly, the load path used is that of the ruby found via PATH, ideally it should use TM_RUBY (when set).

commits.author: Allan Odgaard
commits.summary: Allow folding indented code blocks below ‘when’ statements
commits.body: Since when statements can have their code “inline”, e.g. “when match: do_something” we match lines with ‘when’ keywords either not containing any ‘then’ or colon (‘:’), or where ‘then’ or colon are the last things on the line (except for a trailing line comment).

commits.author: Allan Odgaard
commits.summary: Fix: Text after __END__ marker was still parsed as ruby code
commits.body: This was broken by 6628e6c1872eed32c2e8ec5930649ff115fdb998 which made `variable.other.constant.ruby` match __END__ as well, and as it had a higher priority than our __END__ marker match, it would win.

commits.author: Allan Odgaard
commits.summary: Update how we find the `ri` executable (Documentation for Word)
commits.body: You can set `TM_RUBY_RI` if you need to use a specific version.

commits.author: Stefan Daschek
commits.body:
`Executable.find` is used by commands running with Ruby 1.8 (like for example “Reformat document”), so it has to be compatible with Ruby 1.8.

A nice side-effect of this change is that the tests in `test_executable.rb` can now be run from within TextMate without setting a specific project directory. The Gemfile is no longer necessary, too.

Fixes #128

commits.summary: Add frozen string literal magic comment snippet

commits.author: Stefan Daschek
commits.summary: If Gemfile present, always assume `bundle exec …`
commits.body:
While trying to be smart about whether the requested executable is actually part of the Gemfile was a nice idea, in practice it didn’t work out:

Gems may include executables with names different than the name of the gem itself. Most prominent example: the `rspec` executable is provided by the gem `rspec-core` (for the record: this was causing https://github.com/rspec/rspec.tmbundle/issues/111).

So from now an let’s just assume that if a project has a Gemfile, any executable should be run via `bundle exec …`. If needed, this behaviour can still be changed on a per-project basis by providing a custom binstub or setting `TM_$EXECUTABLE` appropriately.

Fixes #120.
